data.meta_description: Penn Badgley's biggest role since "Gossip Girl" is a charismatic serial killer.
data.text:
Penn Badgley doesnâ€™t actually need to be on the internet to stoke his popularity. Heâ€™s already the internetâ€™s boyfriend, and has been since the original â€œGossip Girlâ€ premiered in 2007.

Badgley became famous at the exact moment when the celebrity-industrial complex, fed by the toxic brew of the gossip sites TMZ and Perez Hilton, was at its most pernicious â€” which was the same moment that teenagers everywhere got their hands on their first iPhones. â€œâ€˜Gossip Girl,â€™ if you think about it, wouldnâ€™t have happened at any other time,â€ Badgley says. â€œThat was the spirit of the show: It was Perez. It was TMZ.â€

Badgley made it through that poisonous period intact. But now, when it comes to joining social media platforms, he is, understandably, apprehensive. Twitter used to suit Badgley best, he being a news-obsessed man of words, but thatâ€™s changed: â€œI canâ€™t really spend much time on that platform anymore,â€ he says. Instagram, too, feels â€œa bit too much like standing on a stage and trying to present,â€ and Badgley doesnâ€™t need that type of exposure.

TikTok, though, seems to 36-year-old Badgley like â€œa place for experimentation â€” and just to honestly have fun.â€ So last fall, he and his producing partner, Nava Kavelin, decided to dig in: â€œBasically, like a couple of old people, we were just going through TikTok, like, â€˜Whatâ€™s going on, on this thing?â€™â€

His first effort at a TikTok video, set to Taylor Swiftâ€™s anthem â€œAnti-Hero,â€ was a nod to Joe Goldberg, the character Badgley plays on his phenomenally popular Netflix series, â€œYou.â€ Joe â€” who in Season 1 is a Manhattan bookstore manager broken by childhood abuse â€” is a charming serial killer whose charisma, physical attractiveness and baggage lead women to fall for him again and again. But then, for one reason or another, whoops!, Joe does it again, killing his various partners and the people close to them. (Netflix has split the 10 episodes of the current fourth season into two parts, with the first five dropping on Feb. 9 â€” and shooting into the streamerâ€™s vaunted No. 1 slot â€” and the second batch set to drop on March 9.)

But back to that TikTok. Badgley is well aware of his earnest image, mostly projected onto him by the public because of his portrayal of Dan Humphrey, the brooding â€œGossip Girlâ€ character he played for six seasons until the show ended in 2012, and now as Joe, the devastatingly devious embodiment of toxic masculinity. And by goofily lip-syncing to Swiftâ€™s chorus â€” â€œIâ€™m the problem, itâ€™s me!â€ â€” heâ€™s showing he can be funny and playful and not that serious at all.

The video went viral, with Swift anointing it in the comments with an â€œOMG!!!!ğŸ¤©â€ Headlines followed, rejoicing that Badgley had joined the TikTok generation. Even his â€œGossip Girlâ€ castmate Chace Crawford saw it. â€œI was dying laughing,â€ Crawford says. â€œI was a tiny bit jealous â€” Iâ€™m like, â€˜God, Penn really knows how to work that social media.â€™ Iâ€™m pretty stuck in 2000. I mean, man, I donâ€™t know how to do shit!â€

Joining TikTok is a small thing. But for Badgley, it serves as an important â€œsignifier,â€ he says. He used to resist his fame, but he says the character of Joe revived him as an actor. With Joe, Badgley says heâ€™s â€œfinally exerting the kind of performer that I am.â€

Before this period, Badgley was less engaged. During â€œGossip Girl,â€ he did a few film roles that felt like he was on the right track, with small parts in â€œEasy Aâ€ in 2010 and â€œMargin Callâ€ the following year. He also starred as the doomed folk singer Jeff Buckley, who drowned at age 30, in the 2012 indie â€œGreetings From Tim Buckley.â€ There were years when Badgley just went through the motions. He even stopped acting for a bit in 2016, in favor of being the lead singer of the band MOTHXR.

But he feels different now, and like any savvy actor in the digital age, heâ€™s using this spotlight to leverage new paths for himself. Badgley wants to do more as an artist â€” producing, directing, creating â€” and heâ€™s excited about whatâ€™s next. â€œThings are so digital, so online,â€ he says. â€œI think youâ€™ve got to be fully in or fully out.â€

Badgley is a producer on â€œYou,â€ and this season, heâ€™s directed his first episode â€” the seasonâ€™s penultimate, titled â€œSheâ€™s Not Thereâ€ â€” which got him into the Directors Guild. Though â€œYouâ€ hasnâ€™t been renewed yet, Badgley and the showâ€™s creative team are expecting that a presumed fifth season would wrap up Joe Goldbergâ€™s twisted story. â€œWeâ€™ve always had a five-season plan for the show,â€ says Sarah Schechter, the chairwoman of Berlanti Productions and an executive producer on â€œYou.â€

As part of being â€œfully in,â€ Badgleyâ€™s formed a production company, Ninth Mode Media, which has borne the podcast â€œPodcrushed.â€ He hosts it with Kavelin and Sophie Ansari, and their interviews with guests such as Lisa Kudrow, Conan Oâ€™Brien, Jenna Ortega (who was on â€œYou,â€ and survived Joe) and Badgleyâ€™s wife, Domino Kirke-Badgley, revolve around sometimes painful excavations of adolescence and middle school memories. The â€œPodcrushedâ€ TikTok account, too, has become another platform for Badgley to create viral content.

And Badgleyâ€™s plans for Ninth Mode go beyond podcasting. The company has secured funding for him to direct his first film â€” which he can begin whenever â€œYouâ€ comes to an end â€” and has optioned the David Sedaris story â€œJamboreeâ€ to be developed as a feature.

Itâ€™s been a long road for Badgley to get here. He began acting professionally at age 12 after he and his mother moved, at his request, from outside Seattle to Los Angeles so he could pursue a career. But to say he has regrets about having been a child actor would be an understatement. His first movie credit was the 2001 queer cult film â€œThe Fluffer,â€ and it serves as an illustration of his conflicted feelings. â€œWhen I read the script, neither my agents, my mom, nor I knew what a fluffer was â€” and I was the first one to find out because I read the script first,â€ Badgley says. â€œThat is a microcosm of the whole thing! Should a 12-year-old be â€¦ ? Letâ€™s go ahead and just say no.â€

He worked steadily as a teenager, mostly on television. He took the GED when he was 13, and when I express surprise at this disclosure, Badgley dismisses the accomplishment, saying he did it only so he didnâ€™t have to have a tutor on set and could work adult hours, â€œwhich makes you more attractive on your rÃ©sumÃ©.â€

Badgleyâ€™s relative anonymity as a young actor ended abruptly during the fall of 2007, when, at age 20, he became an instant celebrity as part of the dazzling â€œGossip Girlâ€ ensemble. The glossy CW soap opera, in which sophisticated high school students plotted and caroused like adults, was a zeitgeist hit, even if its ratings were low. (â€œWe were always the struggling show that was a worldwide hit,â€ Badgley says with a laugh.) But fans were obsessed, and he and his co-stars were paparazzi prey in New York City, where they worked and played. And the rapacious gossip press was especially interested in his romantic relationship with his co-star Blake Lively. â€œBeyond our relationship, I donâ€™t think anybody was going to be interested in me publicly,â€ he says.

â€œIt was a little bit night and day,â€ Badgley says of realizing his life had changed when â€œGossip Girlâ€ premiered. â€œI think the date was Sept. 19, 2007.â€

Badgley and I meet twice to talk, with the first interview taking place in late October in West Hollywood, and the second late last month over breakfast in Brooklyn, close to where he lives with Kirke-Badgley â€” to whom heâ€™s been married since 2017 â€” their toddler and his teenage stepson. During our first conversation, Badgleyâ€™s car had just been stolen off the street in Brooklyn, so he kept having to step away to speak with Kirke-Badgley on the phone about logistics. â€œYou feel kind of betrayed, but you donâ€™t know by who,â€ he says. â€œMy wife, because sheâ€™s there on the ground with my kids, I think sheâ€™s just â€¦ itâ€™s surprisingly emotional. Weâ€™ll be OK. We can get another car. Weâ€™ve got insurance, all that stuff, but it never feels good.â€

During our second meeting, Badgleyâ€™s energy feels lighter, and heâ€™s quick to laugh. He was bearded during our first interview, as he is in Season 4 of â€œYou,â€ but since heâ€™s been in stay-at-home dad mode for a few months, itâ€™s gotten bushier, and his hair is longer too. While it had made sense during the showâ€™s first three seasons for Joe to hide his murderous self behind a more clean-cut look, Badgley pushed for him to have a beard this time â€” and won. But then, â€œI was just wanting the hair to be as long as possible,â€ he says. â€œAnd they were like, â€˜Mmm, less.â€™ We found a happy medium.â€

In person, Badgley is serious and thoughtful. But heâ€™s also affable, dryly funny and open to answering anything, no matter how personal.

More than a decade ago, â€œGossip Girlâ€ was nearing its end. For years, while doing the show, â€œI didnâ€™t want to be in television,â€ he says, and â€œI was biding time a lot with Dan â€” I was not invested. And Iâ€™m not saying itâ€™s a good thing! Iâ€™m saying itâ€™s just what it was.â€

When he looks back on those years, â€œthereâ€™s two ways I see them.â€ â€œFun and fast-pacedâ€ is the first way heâ€™d characterize that era. But underneath was a â€œdark undercurrent that would bottom out in my later 20s.â€ I ask whether any of the darkness was substance abuse-related, and he waves me off. â€œTo be honest, I never struggled with substance,â€ Badgley says. â€œBlake didnâ€™t drink, and I think our relationship in some ways saved me from forcing myself to go down that road.â€

Thatâ€™s interesting phrasing: â€œforcing myself to go down that road.â€ It indicates that when Badgley found himself facing â€œnothing short of a spiritual crisis,â€ he sought solace from all corners: by traveling, exploring Buddhism, trying â€œa lot of physical techniques, from breathing to meditation,â€ and throwing himself into political causes, such as Occupy Wall Street. As for what had provoked this state of emergency, he smiles somewhat bashfully as he answers: â€œLike anybody who experiences some degree of fame and wealth, I was presented with the universal truth that not only does it not make your life better or easier, it actually can greatly complicate things, and make you quite unhappy.â€

He felt isolated; he didnâ€™t know who to trust. â€œI was never anything that I would define as suicidal at all, but I was certainly in a despair,â€ Badgley says. â€œIt had to do with â€˜Do I matter? Do I matter? Does anything matter?â€™ These questions do inform how we feel. The answer that I came upon was â€˜Yes.â€™ I think we all have to come to that. I donâ€™t know how you could come to â€˜Noâ€™ and be happy, so we all have to come to that â€˜Yesâ€™ somehow. Probably repeatedly.â€

Traveling led him circuitously to the Bahaâ€™i faith, through a man he met in Colombia while both were living with the Kogi tribe. This almost sounds like a parody, but the man was the â€œother young white dude from New York City.â€ They didnâ€™t stay in touch, but â€œover the years we just connected in these really serendipitous ways,â€ and through him, Badgley discovered â€œthe mystical poetry of Bahaâ€™uâ€™llahâ€ â€” the founder of Bahaâ€™i, who lived in Persia in the 19th century â€” â€œwhich really started speaking to my heart.â€

In Badgleyâ€™s telling, it was in August 2014, after the death of Michael Brown and the #BlackLivesMatter protests began in Ferguson, Mo., that he went further into the world of Bahaâ€™i. â€œI was thinking a lot about social change, social action, social transformation â€” but also my own transformation, my own change,â€ he says. He saw Bahaâ€™i teachings, which say that weâ€™re all connected, as offering â€œthe most committed pathway from individual transformation to social transformation.â€

â€œI thought to myself, â€˜If I really want to participate in the betterment of the world, I think that I should become a Bahaâ€™i,â€™â€ Badgley says.

He formally declared himself Bahaâ€™i in May 2015, â€œbut thatâ€™s just a step along the way,â€ Badgley says. Heâ€™s since found his place in â€œthis really interesting, eccentric group of people,â€ which includes his â€œPodcrushedâ€ co-hosts. Consequently, of all the performing arts, â€œsinging is the thing I do the most,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s a part of my spiritual practice â€” my prayers are often me singing.â€ When heâ€™s not in production, he wakes up with his young son, and they sing together.

It certainly seems like Badgley has found peace. And heâ€™s ready for what comes after â€œYouâ€ as well. In the opinion of Sera Gamble, the â€œYouâ€ showrunner whoâ€™s worked with Badgley for almost six years, â€œI think he has more than proven that heâ€™s someone people really, really want to watch.â€ She pauses, then laughs. â€œBut, you know, Penn gets to do whatever he wants.â€

So what does Badgley want? Heâ€™s been starring on television shows off and on for more than 20 years. â€œI did most of that without any kids or spouse, you know? Or any real consideration for family â€” and now all thatâ€™s very different,â€ he says. â€œAnd I didnâ€™t do it with anything other than the pipe dreams of being a producer or a director or writer. Now Iâ€™m in the DGA, and Iâ€™m a producer on the podcast and have the rights to a Sedaris story. â€¦ â€

Badgley stops talking for a bit, appearing to consider what lies ahead: more acting, sure, but also producing, podcasting, directing, writing. He then looks resolute as he finishes his thought. â€œIf this is how Iâ€™m going to exist in a way that for me is sustainable â€” emotionally and spiritually and psychologically â€” then this is how Iâ€™m gonna do it.â€

Itâ€™s funny to think that when Badgley was first approached about â€œYou,â€ he absolutely did not want to do it.

Playing someone like Joe Goldberg just wasnâ€™t appealing, despite it being alluring to Badgley that the character subversively took â€œthe tropes of Dan Humphrey, put it in a blender and sort of reconfigured and re-served it,â€ he says. But having found peace in his life, he had little desire to play someone so awful.

Less typically, he was also concerned with how inherently sexual the role was, and how many intimate scenes he would have to film. In later seasons, the show has had an intimacy coordinator, but when production began in 2017, that job didnâ€™t exist. The whole series revolves around Joeâ€™s romantic fixations, and how he gets the women heâ€™s fallen for to submit to his charms. â€œYouâ€ has a ton of sex.

Badgley speaks carefully as he describes his discomfort with sex scenes, â€œhaving done a fair amount of them in my career.â€ â€œItâ€™s not a place where Iâ€™ve blurred lines,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s almost nothing I could say with more consecration. That aspect of Hollywood has always been very disturbing to me â€” and that aspect of the job, that mercurial boundary â€” has always been something that I actually donâ€™t want to play with at all.â€ Heâ€™s also now older than his romantic interests on the show. â€œDidnâ€™t used to be the case,â€ he says.

In fact, Badgley wishes he didnâ€™t have to do any sex scenes. â€œItâ€™s important to me in my real life to not have them.â€ (The scenes in the current season of â€œYouâ€ are all done fully clothed.)

â€œYour â€˜real lifeâ€™?â€ I ask.

â€œMy fidelity in my relationship,â€ Badgley says. â€œItâ€™s important to me. And actually, it was one of the reasons that I initially wanted to turn the role down. I didnâ€™t tell anybody that. But that is why.â€

But Kirke-Badgley â€œencouragedâ€ him to play Joe: â€œAnd I wasnâ€™t going to listen to anyone more than her.â€

As those conversations with his wife were happening, he was also being won over by executive producers Greg Berlanti, Schechter and Gamble. â€œI felt his energy change when he realized that we were all on the same page about why we would tell a story about a character like this â€” it was in no way to justify Joe,â€ Gamble says. â€œIt was to vivisect him, to figure out why a milder version of this character is the lead in most romantic stories in the Western canon.â€

At one point, Badgley remembers, Berlanti referred to â€œYouâ€ as â€œa love storyâ€ â€” which caused Badgley to bristle. He told Berlanti, â€œI donâ€™t think of this as a love story. But just assuming that it is, for a moment, then what is it saying about love?â€

â€œGreg took the perfect dramatic pause,â€ Badgley remembers, â€œand he said, â€˜Iâ€™m not sure, but I think weâ€™ll discover that together.â€™ A role in a television show had never offered me that level of collaboration. And thatâ€™s what caused me to stop my retreat from the possibility and be like, â€˜Hmm, thatâ€™s cool.â€™â€

So appealing is Badgley as Joe Goldberg that a lustful segment of rabid â€œYouâ€ fans frequently declare on social media that they want nothing more than to be stalked and kidnapped by him. This disturbing, persistent Joe-as-thirst-trap phenomenon is something Badgley is horrified by, and has addressed publicly a number of times, including answering a simple â€œNo thxâ€ to a fan who tweeted, â€œkidnap me pls.â€

As Schechter puts it: â€œItâ€™s not easy to have the world rooting for you when youâ€™ve murdered as many people as Joe Goldberg has.â€ She remembers that first wave of viewersâ€™ unhealthy feelings for Joe. â€œEveryone was like, â€˜I want Joe Goldberg to murder me,â€™â€ she says. â€œAnd Penn was like, â€˜Ladies, no! Do not. Do not be attracted to this man.â€™ Heâ€™s just a very solid human being who recognizes the importance of playing this part and the chance to showcase and create discussion around toxic masculinity.â€

Originally based on a book by Caroline Kepnes, â€œYouâ€ is an addictive, utterly mad character study while also being a layered satire about the aforementioned toxic masculinity. The success of â€œYouâ€ rests largely on Badgley â€” the only actor whoâ€™s appeared in all four seasons â€” and his ability to charm the audience into sticking with the show.

Without Netflix, though, â€œYouâ€ would have been one and done. It premiered on Lifetime in September 2018 and was an absolute mismatch for the â€œTelevision for Womenâ€ cable network â€” a total of 650,000 people watched it. â€œYouâ€ bombed, and Lifetime canceled it that December.

But before the show premiered, Netflix had signed on as its streaming partner, licensing its reruns and international rights. So when the first season of the already canceled â€œYouâ€ dropped on the streamer on Dec. 26, 2018, it became a massive, meme-generating smash, and the conversation around the show was suddenly ubiquitous. Back then, Netflix was reluctant to share its ratings, but â€œYouâ€ proved the rare exception: After the show hit the streamer, the company tweeted that â€œYouâ€ was on track to be watched by 40 million households within its first four weeks.

Having turned the series into an international phenomenon, Netflix, of course, resurrected it, quickly putting a second season into production. According to Netflixâ€™s publicly available stats, â€œYouâ€ has only grown: Its third season spent eight weeks in the streamerâ€™s global Top 10, and reached the Top 10s in 94 countries. Itâ€™s still wildly popular in Season 4 â€” a rarity for a Netflix show.

â€œYouâ€ is â€” among its other attributes â€” a fascinating exercise in the power of perspective and the cameraâ€™s gaze, and since Joe is the point-of-view character, itâ€™s hard not to worry for him, and fear heâ€™ll be caught. â€œYou forget that heâ€™s irredeemable! And youâ€™re constantly wondering if he can redeem himself,â€ Badgley says. Which makes Joeâ€™s shockingly violent nature and overall loathsome existence even more unsettling. â€œEverybody must have moments when theyâ€™re like, â€˜How do I like this show so much?â€™â€

Over four seasons, Joe has romanced/murdered his way through New York City, L.A., Madre Linda (a fictional, affluent Bay Area suburb) â€” and now, in Season 4, London.

But wherever Joe goes, there he is. Gamble says, â€œWhat weâ€™ve basically been telling ourselves for these four seasons is that Joe goes crazier every season.â€

In London, Joe has a new identity as Jonathan Moore, a university professor whoâ€™s come to Europe to stalk his Season 3 quarry, Marienne (Tati Gabrielle). But when he tries to start over, embedding in a new group of highsociety friends, he finds himself in an all-too-familiar situation â€” that is, with a dead body in his apartment. The season then takes the form of a whodunit, as Joe seeks out the tormentor whoâ€™s setting him up by killing others in the group. By the end of the fifth episode, Joe has discovered what he thinks is the answer.

Naturally, he has a love interest this season in Kate, played by Charlotte Ritchie. Like so many before her, Kate saw the darkness in Joe before becoming captivated by him.

But this is â€œYou,â€ so nothing can be taken at face value, and where Joe ends up in the finale will shock even the most astute viewers. â€œThey always manage to stick the landing,â€ Badgley says. â€œThe triple axel of every season finale is very hard.â€

As the streaming age of television matures, there have been more and more bumps along the way, beginning with Netflixâ€™s correction last year, which caused the whole industry (and Wall Street) to question whether this model will ever pay off. But for all that agita, â€œYouâ€ is one of the periodâ€™s great successes.

As for how the show will end â€” will Joe be justly punished after everything heâ€™s done? Badgley finds the question interesting. â€œIs killing Joe enough?â€ he wonders. â€œWhoever kills him is brought down to his level.â€ He has an idea of what Berlanti and Gamble have in mind, but wonâ€™t say what it is. â€œI think itâ€™s the only way it can go,â€ he says.

Putting those questions aside, directing an episode this season fulfilled a long-standing wish. When I ask what surprised him the most about it, he answers quickly. â€œMaybe that I really loved it? Not that I expected not to, but â€” I loved it,â€ he says. â€œIt reinvented the show for me.â€

Despite how much Badgley took to directing, heâ€™s pretty sure he doesnâ€™t want to do it again during a presumed fifth season of â€œYou.â€ It was too much. After a day of acting, heâ€™d come back to his place in London â€” he was staying with Kirke-Badgleyâ€™s aunt during production â€” and work with editors in Los Angeles over Zoom.

â€œI was managing it, and not even feeling exhausted at all â€” I was very alive to the work,â€ he says. â€œAnd it was really enjoyable, but extreme and unsustainable. And if my family had been there, I would have had zero time for them.â€

Even if that does turn out to be the only episode of â€œYouâ€ Badgley directs, let it be known that it contains a Taylor Swift reference. So does that mean Joe is a Swiftie?

â€œI think, unfortunately, he would despise her,â€ Badgley says. â€œBecause sheâ€™s successful and blond, maybe? I donâ€™t know, but I think he would.â€
